title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [25 august 1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [25 August 1868]
text: tuesdayTuesdayevenineveningMy dear Walti received your letter to day with the nice envelopes all stampdstamped so nicely i feel as if i ougthought to write a nice letter the first that i saw of those stamped enpelopesenvelopes i didentdidn't know whether they were the lawful or bogus ones i sent Edd next door when Mr ray kept a jeweleryjewelry store to get some and he got those and i was so green i had to ask georgeGeorge if they would go and to tease me he told me letters wouldentwouldn't go with them envelopes i told him i gave 4 cent a peicepiece for them and they ought to be good then he said he gessdguessed theyedthey'd go i am glad to hear you have been so well this summer walterWalter it is quite warm here and terribly dusty i am in hopes it will rain as it has the appearance of it georgeGeorge has been to the country for three days he went up in the glen cove boat to roslinRoslynn and went out sailing and fishing and had a pretty good time i believe whethewhether his gal went with him or not i dontdon't know he got back sundaySunday night and is inspecting on the small pipe to day as the large has not come yet he and mrMr. Lane seems to get along very well jeffyJeffy wrote to me after he was home that georgeGeorge would not be discharged as long as mrMr. Lane was there georgeGeorge might save something i think if he was saving but these bad gals and amusements takes the green he she's saving enoughfenough toward me i know i dontdon't know how he would be if you didintdidn't send me so much but i think i shouldentshouldn't get along so well if i depended altogether on him) O waltWalt i feel sometimes like the irishIrish when you give em any thing they always say long may you live and be blessed) but i dontdon't know as i ought to complain of georgeGeorge he dontdon't know how much it takes to keep house he is very good to me so long as i dontdon't interfere with his affairs) the house is getting along very well they are putting up the stairs now so you didentdidn't like your new place as well as the old one well a person will get attached to any place where they live a long time)i am pretty well now i have been troubled with a pain in my side but i put mustard on and it is better but very sore) walterWalter dear if you send me a money order next week i wish you would put a dollar in with itgood by walterWalter deari am glad you have set the time to comei think the prices must be in the country as i haventhaven't seen them lately Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [25 August 1868]
